Situation1: This is the last weekend before the partner relocates abroad for months.
Expectation2: Communicate with pilots to provide instructions and updates
Situation2: Cloud tops are rising quickly, and several pilots await revised climb instructions.
Story: I glance at my phone, my partner’s message lighting up the screen: “Can’t wait for our last weekend together.” My heart aches, knowing he leaves for months tomorrow. I promised him this time, no distractions, just us. But the headset crackles in my ear, and the radar blips multiply. The weather is shifting fast—cloud tops are rising, and pilots are calling in, waiting for my instructions. My supervisor’s voice is tense: “We need you focused. Pilots need those climb updates now.” I feel the weight of both worlds pressing in. My partner expects my presence, my warmth, my undivided attention. The pilots expect my calm, my precision, my vigilance. I stare at the clock, torn between the love I want to hold onto and the responsibility I can’t abandon. My hands tremble as I hover between the phone and the radio, knowing I can’t be in both places at once.
